abstract.text: Changes to the QuickTime File Format.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Updated the color atom (
) to include information on new color standards, including DCI P3, P3 D65, and ITU-R BT.2020.
A new facility for timed metadata tracks has been incorporated, see
. Introduce
track reference type, see
. Added more well-known metadata data types, see
Updated the section on closed caption tracks.
Corrected the values for
and
Added
Added
, and
to
Added
, and
Added
In
, expanded the description of
and added
with related section Media Characteristic Tags.
Explained alternate groups in
Corrected structure of
and
in
General Structure of a Sample Description in
includes emphasized importance of data size due to occasional terminating zeroes.
now documents the reserved integer after the text size.
“Audio track” changed to “sound track” for consistency.
Deprecated
data reference.
The sound sample description v2 format along with the definition of two new sound sample description extensions, see
New atoms for the display of track aperture in different modes, see
New sample atoms for handling out-of-order movie samples, see
, which treats how to handle temporal positioning of AAC audio data explicitly.
The Macintosh language codes table has been updated with current language names, see
and the related
defined.
Corrected the order of fields described in the
structure.
Added description of clip-based metadata and specific key/value pairs for location metadata.
First public release of complete, updated
QuickTime File Format Specification
with information about atoms and atom types.
Added licensing information and disclaimer for developers.
A QuickTime file may now contain a file type compatibility atom. See
A movie atom may now contain a movie profile atom. See
A track atom may now contain a track profile atom. See
Video sample descriptions may now contain a pixel aspect ratio atom for non-square pixels. See
Video sample descriptions may now also contain a color parameter atom. See
Video sample descriptions may now a clean aperture atom. See
MPEG-4 video and audio sample descriptions may now contain elementary stream descriptor atoms. See
) and
Modified introductory sections and atom descriptions; updated artwork and edited for technical accuracy.
The sound description record has been expanded to represent variable bit-rate compression more accurately. See
The section describing MPEG-4 audio has been modified. See MPEG-4 Audio in
It is now recommended that the file creation and modification times be set using UTC, rather than local time zones. See
User data text may now be encoded using either Macintosh text encoding or ISO text encoding (Unicode). See User Data Text Strings and Language Codes in
It is now possible to specify languages using either Macintosh language codes or ISO language codes. See

abstract.text: Position a source audio signal in a sound track to handle encoder delay.

doc://com.apple.qtff/documentation/Quick.title: Audio priming-handling encoder delay in AAC

abstract.text: QuickTime movies store date and time information in Macintosh date format.
Store closed captioning for QuickTime movies.
Indicate the language associated with a particular object using language codes.
Create collections of tracks that all serve the same purpose, where any track in the group can be substituted for another in a movie.

doc://com.apple.qtff/documentation/Quick.title: Preparing sound and subtitle alternate groups for use with Apple devices

abstract.text: Atoms that describe samples, which are single elements in a sequence of time-ordered data.
Sound sample formats that QuickTime supports.
A sound sample description contains information that defines how to interpret sound media data.
Store text data used for subtitles in QuickTime movies.
Store timed metadata in QuickTime movies with a track structure.
Four bytes that indicate a type of data that QuickTime supports.
Atoms you use to define and store data associated with a QuickTime object.
An object-oriented file format for the storage and exchange of digital media between devices, applications, and operating systems.
An atom that stores the media information for media types such as timed metadata, text, MPEG, time code, and music.
An extension that defines the relationship between the pixels in a stored image and a canonical rectangular region of a video system from which it was captured or to which it will be displayed.
A required extension for uncompressed Y´CbCr data formats.
An atom that represents media language information.
An atom that identifies the file type specifications with which the file is compatible.
A required extension to the audio sample description for MPEG-4 audio.

fragments.text: MPEG-4 elementary sound stream descriptor atom ('esds')

abstract.text: A required extension to the video sample description for MPEG-4 video.
An atom that defines the structure used for all types of metadata stored within the metadata atom.
An atom that summarizes the features and complexity of a movie.
An extension that specifies the height-to-width ratio of pixels found in the video sample.
An atom that stores information that allows you to decode samples in the media.
An updated sound sample description that adds high resolution audio.
An atom that contains information about text media.
An atom that governs how the timecode text is displayed.
A container atom that stores information for video correction in the form of three required atoms.
An atom that indicates not to automatically select this track.
A 16-bit integer that identifies a collection of movie tracks that contain alternate data for one another.
A child atom of movie atoms or track atoms.
An atom that defines relationships with tracks of a specific type.
